research_basis: Based on Big Five (BFI-10/20), Communication Styles Inventory (CSI), Four-Factor Communication Model, Interpersonal Circumplex Theory, Bartholomew's Attachment Theory, Field Dependence/Independence Research, and Achievement/Affiliation/Power Motivation Theory

occupation.question: What do you do for work/study?

primary_style.question: When communicating, you naturally focus on:
options: Results and action - 'What do we need to accomplish?'
Process and analysis - 'How should we approach this systematically?'
People and relationships - 'Who will be affected and how do they feel?'
Ideas and possibilities - 'What if we tried something completely different?'
primary_style.research_note: Based on 4-Factor Communication Model (Action, Process, People, Ideas)

directness.question: When you disagree with someone, you typically:
options: Address it immediately and directly
Wait for the right moment but speak clearly
Give subtle hints and hope they notice
Avoid confrontation and find workarounds
Completely avoid the topic
directness.research_note: Based on assertiveness research from Interpersonal Circumplex Theory

expressiveness.question: In conversations, people often notice you are:
options: Very animated - gestures, facial expressions, vocal variety
Moderately expressive - some gestures and tone variation
Steady - consistent tone and minimal gestures
Reserved - controlled expressions and measured speech
Very contained - minimal emotional display
expressiveness.research_note: Based on Communication Styles Inventory (CSI) expressiveness dimension

conversation_pace.question: Your natural speaking and response style is:
options: Quick and energetic - jump right in, fast responses
Steady and engaging - normal pace with good flow
Thoughtful and measured - pause to consider before responding
Deliberate and careful - take time to craft responses
Slow and reflective - long pauses, deep consideration
conversation_pace.research_note: Based on temporal aspects of communication from conversation analysis research

extraversion.question: You are someone who is talkative, energetic, and gets excitement from social interactions:
options: Strongly disagree - I'm reserved and prefer quiet environments
Somewhat disagree - I'm more introverted than extroverted
Neither agree nor disagree - I'm balanced
Somewhat agree - I'm generally outgoing and social
Strongly agree - I'm very talkative and energetic around others

conscientiousness.question: You are someone who is organized, responsible, and gets tasks done efficiently:
options: Strongly disagree - I'm spontaneous and dislike rigid schedules
Somewhat disagree - I'm more flexible than organized
Neither agree nor disagree - I'm moderately organized
Somewhat agree - I value organization and follow through
Strongly agree - I'm very disciplined and detail-oriented

agreeableness.question: You are someone who is cooperative, trusting, and tends to assume others have good intentions:
options: Strongly disagree - I'm competitive and skeptical of others
Somewhat disagree - I'm more assertive than accommodating
Neither agree nor disagree - I balance cooperation with self-interest
Somewhat agree - I generally trust and help others
Strongly agree - I'm very cooperative and assume the best in people

neuroticism.question: You are someone who stays calm under pressure and rarely feels anxious or stressed:
options: Strongly disagree - I often feel anxious and get stressed easily
Somewhat disagree - I'm more prone to worry than most
Neither agree nor disagree - I have normal stress levels
Somewhat agree - I handle stress well and stay fairly calm
Strongly agree - I'm very emotionally stable and rarely anxious
neuroticism.research_note: Big Five Neuroticism (reverse-scored for Emotional Stability, BFI-10 validated)

openness.question: You are someone who is curious, imaginative, and enjoys exploring new ideas and experiences:
options: Strongly disagree - I prefer routine and conventional approaches
Somewhat disagree - I'm more practical than creative
Neither agree nor disagree - I'm moderately open to new things
Somewhat agree - I enjoy novelty and creative thinking
Strongly agree - I'm very curious and love exploring new possibilities
openness.research_note: Big Five Openness to Experience (BFI-10 validated items)

conversation_initiation.question: In group conversations, you typically:
options: Lead and direct the conversation flow
Contribute actively when topics interest you
Listen mostly and add thoughtful comments
Wait for others to include you
Prefer to observe without much participation
conversation_initiation.research_note: Based on social dominance and interaction patterns research

conflict_response.question: When someone disagrees with your opinion, your instinct is to:
options: Argue your point with facts and logic
Try to understand their perspective first
Compromise to maintain harmony
Change the subject to avoid tension
Get frustrated but stay quiet
conflict_response.research_note: Based on interpersonal circumplex theory and conflict styles

emotional_processing.question: When you're feeling strong emotions (excited, upset, frustrated), you typically:
options: Express them immediately and openly
Share them with close friends/family
Process them internally before sharing
Keep them private but let them show nonverbally
Hide them completely and deal with them alone
emotional_processing.research_note: Based on emotional regulation and expression research

decision_approach.question: When making important decisions, you mainly rely on:
options: Logical analysis of facts and data
Gut feelings and intuition
Advice from trusted people
Past experiences and proven methods
Careful research and multiple perspectives
decision_approach.research_note: Based on cognitive decision-making styles research

conversation_topics.question: What 3-5 topics do you find yourself talking about most often? (e.g., work, movies, travel, technology, relationships)

core_values.question: What matters most to you in relationships and life?
options: Honesty and authenticity above all
Loyalty and mutual support
Personal growth and learning
Fun and shared experiences
Achievement and success
core_values.research_note: Based on values theory and relationship research

social_energy.question: Your ideal way to spend free time is:
options: Large groups and social events
Small gatherings with close friends
One-on-one quality time
Solo activities with optional company
Complete solitude and personal projects
social_energy.research_note: Based on extraversion and social preference research

humor_style.question: Your humor style tends to be:
options: Quick wit and clever wordplay
Playful teasing and silly jokes
Dry sarcasm and deadpan delivery
Warm storytelling and dad jokes
Observational comedy about everyday life
humor_style.research_note: Based on humor styles research and personality correlations

attachment_security.question: In close relationships, you typically feel:
options: Comfortable with intimacy and trusting others easily
Want closeness but worry about being hurt or rejected
Prefer emotional distance and value independence highly
Crave intimacy but fear others don't want to be as close
Comfortable depending on others when needed
attachment_security.research_note: Based on Bartholomew's 4-category adult attachment model (secure, fearful-avoidant, dismissing-avoidant, preoccupied)

relationship_conflict.question: When relationships hit challenges or conflicts, you tend to:
options: Address issues directly and work toward resolution
Withdraw and give yourself space to process
Become anxious and seek immediate reassurance
Try to fix things by being extra accommodating
Analyze the situation logically before responding
relationship_conflict.research_note: Based on attachment theory and conflict resolution styles

emotional_intimacy.question: When someone wants to get emotionally close to you, you:
options: Welcome it and naturally open up in return
Feel comfortable but prefer gradual deepening
Feel somewhat uncomfortable but try to reciprocate
Instinctively create some distance or change topics
Analyze their motives before deciding how to respond
emotional_intimacy.research_note: Based on attachment theory research on intimacy comfort levels

support_seeking.question: When you're stressed or upset, you typically:
options: Reach out to trusted friends or family for support
Process internally before sharing with select people
Want comfort but struggle to ask for it directly
Prefer to handle things completely on your own
Seek practical advice more than emotional support
support_seeking.research_note: Based on attachment theory and help-seeking behaviors

information_style.question: When learning something new, you prefer to:
options: Break it down into detailed steps and learn systematically
Get the big picture first, then fill in details
Jump in and learn by trial and error
Connect it to things you already know
Study all angles before forming conclusions
information_style.research_note: Based on field dependence/independence and cognitive style research

problem_solving.question: When facing complex problems, you naturally:
options: Analyze each component separately and build up solutions
Look for patterns and creative connections
Try multiple approaches until something works
Seek advice and collaborate with others
Step back to see the whole situation clearly
problem_solving.research_note: Based on cognitive processing style research and problem-solving approaches

attention_focus.question: You tend to focus on:
options: Specific details and concrete facts
Overall patterns and abstract concepts
Immediate practical applications
How things affect people and relationships
Multiple perspectives and possibilities
attention_focus.research_note: Based on field dependence/independence and attention research

decision_speed.question: When making decisions, you typically:
options: Decide quickly based on gut instinct
Gather some info then decide fairly quickly
Take time to consider multiple options carefully
Research extensively before deciding
Seek input from others before choosing
decision_speed.research_note: Based on cognitive style and decision-making research

primary_motivation.question: What motivates you most in life is:
options: Achieving concrete goals and measurable success
Building meaningful relationships and helping others
Learning, growing, and expanding your understanding
Having new experiences and avoiding boredom
Being recognized for your unique contributions
primary_motivation.research_note: Based on achievement/affiliation/power motivation and self-determination theory

success_definition.question: You feel most accomplished when:
options: You exceed your own high standards and goals
You've made a positive difference in others' lives
You've mastered something challenging or complex
You've pushed boundaries and tried new things
You've gained respect and recognition from others
success_definition.research_note: Based on achievement motivation and values research

challenge_response.question: When facing difficult goals, you:
options: Push harder and work more intensively
Break it down into manageable steps
Seek support and collaborate with others
Look for creative or unconventional approaches
Reassess whether the goal is worth pursuing
challenge_response.research_note: Based on achievement motivation and persistence research

energy_source.question: You get most energized by:
options: Completing tasks and seeing concrete results
Connecting with people and building relationships
Discovering new ideas and insights
Variety, change, and novel experiences
Having influence and making important decisions
energy_source.research_note: Based on intrinsic/extrinsic motivation and energy source research

changelog.changes: Initial question set - migrated from hardcoded questions
Complete redesign based on psychological research: Big Five (BFI-10/20), Communication Styles Inventory, 4-Factor Communication Model, Interpersonal Circumplex Theory

Added comprehensive psychological categories: relationship patterns (attachment theory), cognitive processing (field dependence/independence), and motivation drives (achievement/affiliation/power theory)
